A flashlight produces light by converting the chemical energy stored within its batteries into light energy. This process begins when the flashlight is turned on, and the electrical circuit inside it closes. The chemical energy in the batteries is then released as electrical energy, which flows through the flashlight's circuit to the light source, typically an LED (light-emitting diode) or an incandescent bulb.

In the case of an LED, the electrical energy excites electrons, creating photons as the electrons move within the semiconductor material, thus emitting light. For incandescent bulbs, the electrical current passes through a filament, usually made of tungsten. The resistance of the filament to the electrical current causes it to heat up to a point where it glows, producing light.

This conversion process is efficient in transforming the stored chemical energy into visible light, enabling the flashlight to serve as a portable light source.
